channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07129-1

Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Developmental dynamics of two bipotent thymic epithelial progenitor types
item.dc:creator: Anja Nusser
Sagar
Jeremy B. Swann
Brigitte Krauth
Dagmar Diekhoff
Lesly Calderon
Christiane Happe
Dominic Grün
Thomas Boehm

item.title: How to enhance lab-team efficiency with tools from the tech industry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00312-4

Using freely available software can help to maximize productivity and avoid collaboration pain points.
item.dc:title: How to enhance lab-team efficiency with tools from the tech industry
item.dc:creator: Lathan Liou
Akshay Swaminathan

item.title: Number of Black UK professors rises by 25% in one year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00249-8

Initiatives such as grass-roots campaigns are likely to have contributed to the uptick, but barriers to progress remain.
item.dc:title: Number of Black UK professors rises by 25% in one year
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: In the AI science boom, beware: your results are only as good as your data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00306-2

Machine-learning systems are voracious data consumers — but trustworthy results require more vetting both before and after publication.
item.dc:title: In the AI science boom, beware: your results are only as good as your data
item.dc:creator: Hunter Moseley

item.title: Passion, curiosity and perseverance: my mission to capture women in science on camera
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00297-0

Genetics researcher Elisabetta Citterio explains why she felt compelled to photograph 57 women who work in STEM fields.
item.dc:title: Passion, curiosity and perseverance: my mission to capture women in science on camera
item.dc:creator: Josie Glausiusz

item.title: This AI learnt language by seeing the world through a baby’s eyes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00288-1

A neural network that taught itself to recognize objects using the filmed experiences of a single infant could offer new insights into how humans learn.
item.dc:title: This AI learnt language by seeing the world through a baby’s eyes
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Why autoimmune disease is more common in women: X chromosome holds clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 February 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00267-6

Rogue antibodies are drawn to the protein–RNA coating on half of the X chromosomes in an XX cell.
item.dc:title: Why autoimmune disease is more common in women: X chromosome holds clues
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07122-8

Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.dc:creator: Tyler Poppenwimer
Itay Mayrose
Niv DeMalach

item.title: A glacier’s ‘memory’ is fading because of climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00244-z

The environmental record preserved in ice high atop a Swiss mountain has been partially lost.
item.dc:title: A glacier’s ‘memory’ is fading because of climate change

item.title: How do otters protect salt marshes from erosion? Shellfishly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00217-2

Sea otters inadvertently protect the vegetation that binds sandy shorelines together.
item.dc:title: How do otters protect salt marshes from erosion? Shellfishly
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Why human brain cells grow so slowly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00280-9

Some human neurons take years to reach maturity; an epigenetic ‘brake’ could be responsible.
item.dc:title: Why human brain cells grow so slowly
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Ancient DNA solves the mystery of who made a set of stone tools
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00290-7

Analysis of stone tools and DNA reveals when modern humans reached northern Europe, and why human brain cells grow so slowly.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA solves the mystery of who made a set of stone tools
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Stereodivergent 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes by charge relocation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06938-0

We introduce a method for the direct 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes, based on a concept termed ‘charge relocation’, which enables stereodivergent access to 1,3-difunctionalized products of either syn- or anti-configuration from unactivated alkenes.
item.dc:title: Stereodivergent 1,3-difunctionalization of alkenes by charge relocation
item.dc:creator: Bogdan R. Brutiu
Giulia Iannelli
Margaux Riomet
Daniel Kaiser
Nuno Maulide

item.title: Establishing reaction networks in the 16-electron sulfur reduction reaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06918-4

We investigate the mechanism underlying the sulfur reduction reaction that plays a central role in high-capacity lithium sulfur batteries, highlighting the electrocatalytic approach as a promising strategy for tackling the fundamental challenges associated with these batteries.
item.dc:title: Establishing reaction networks in the 16-electron sulfur reduction reaction
item.dc:creator: Rongli Liu
Ziyang Wei
Lele Peng
Leyuan Zhang
Arava Zohar

Xiangfeng Duan

item.title: Fertilizer management for global ammonia emission reduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07020-z

A machine learning model for generating crop-specific and spatially explicit NH3 emission factors globally shows that global NH3 emissions in 2018 were lower than previous estimates that did not fully consider fertilizer management practices.
item.dc:title: Fertilizer management for global ammonia emission reduction
item.dc:creator: Peng Xu
Geng Li

item.title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol is an endogenous suppressor of ferroptosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06878-9

Proferroptotic activity of 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase is shown along with an unexpected prosurvival function of its substrate, 7-dehydrocholesterol, indicating a cell-intrinsic mechanism that could be used by cancer cells to protect phospholipids from oxidative damage and escape ferroptosis.
item.dc:title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol is an endogenous suppressor of ferroptosis

item.title: An epigenetic barrier sets the timing of human neuronal maturation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06984-8

The slow maturation of human neurons is regulated by epigenetic modification in nascent neurons, mediated by EZH2, EHMT1, EHMT2 and DOT1L.
item.dc:title: An epigenetic barrier sets the timing of human neuronal maturation
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Ciceri

item.title: Matrix viscoelasticity promotes liver cancer progression in the pre-cirrhotic liver
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06991-9

Structural changes mediated by advanced glycation end-products enhance extracellular matrix viscoelasticity, and that viscoelasticity can promote cancer progression in vivo, independent of stiffness.
item.dc:title: Matrix viscoelasticity promotes liver cancer progression in the pre-cirrhotic liver
item.dc:creator: Weiguo Fan

item.title: Single-photon superradiance in individual caesium lead halide quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07001-8

Excitonic single-photon superradiance is reported in individual perovskite quantum dots with a sub-100 ps radiative decay time, almost as short as the reported exciton coherence time.
item.dc:title: Single-photon superradiance in individual caesium lead halide quantum dots
item.dc:creator: Chenglian Zhu
Simon C. Boehme

Anastasiia Moskalenko

Maksym V. Kovalenko
Gabriele Rainò

item.title: Single-neuronal elements of speech production in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06982-w

Neuropixels recordings from the language-dominant prefrontal cortex reveal a structured organization of planned words, an encoding cascade of phonetic representations by prefrontal neurons in humans and a cellular process that could support the production of speech.
item.dc:title: Single-neuronal elements of speech production in humans
item.dc:creator: Arjun R. Khanna

item.title: Oxygen-evolving photosystem II structures during S<sub>1</sub>–S<sub>2</sub>–S<sub>3</sub> transitions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06987-5

Serial femtosecond crystallography reveals the structural dynamics of photosystem II during the S-state transitions that produce dioxygen, providing insight into electron transfer, water insertion, proton release and O–O bond formation on sub-microsecond timescales.
item.dc:title: Oxygen-evolving photosystem II structures during S<sub>1</sub>–S<sub>2</sub>–S<sub>3</sub> transitions

item.title: Homo sapiens reached the higher latitudes of Europe by 45,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06923-7

Through archaeological excavation, morphological and proteomic taxonomic identification, mitochondrial DNA analysis and direct radiocarbon dating of human remains, a study reports the presence of Homo sapiens in Germany north of the Alps more than 45,000 years ago.
item.dc:title: Homo sapiens reached the higher latitudes of Europe by 45,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: Dorothea Mylopotamitaki

item.title: Conformational ensembles of the human intrinsically disordered proteome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07004-5

A computational model generates conformational ensembles of 28,058 intrinsically disordered proteins and regions (IDRs) in the human proteome and sheds light on the relationship between sequence, conformational properties and functions of IDRs.
item.dc:title: Conformational ensembles of the human intrinsically disordered proteome
item.dc:creator: Giulio Tesei
Anna Ida Trolle
Nicolas Jonsson
Johannes Betz
Frederik E. Knudsen
Francesco Pesce
Kristoffer E. Johansson
Kresten Lindorff-Larsen

item.title: Top-predator recovery abates geomorphic decline of a coastal ecosystem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06959-9

Sea otters recolonizing an estuary in California indirectly reduce erosion by reducing burrowing crab abundance, suggesting that restoring predators could be a key mechanism to improve the stability of coastal wetlands and other ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Top-predator recovery abates geomorphic decline of a coastal ecosystem
item.dc:creator: Brent B. Hughes
Kathryn M. Beheshti
M. Tim Tinker
Christine Angelini
Charlie Endris
Lee Murai

Joseph A. Tomoleoni

Brian R. Silliman

item.title: Stress response silencing by an E3 ligase mutated in neurodegeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06985-7

The E3 ligase SIFI is identified as a dedicated silencing factor of the integrated stress response, a finding that has implications for the development of therapeutics for neurodegenerative diseases caused by mitochondrial protein import stress.
item.dc:title: Stress response silencing by an E3 ligase mutated in neurodegeneration
item.dc:creator: Diane L. Haakonsen
Michael Heider
Andrew J. Ingersoll
Kayla Vodehnal
Samuel R. Witus
Takeshi Uenaka
Marius Wernig
Michael Rapé

item.title: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06917-5

We develop a proton-exchange membrane system that reduces CO2 to formic acid at a catalyst that is derived from waste lead–acid batteries and in which a lattice carbon activation mechanism contributes.
item.dc:title: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.dc:creator: Wensheng Fang

item.title: The Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study enables generational genetic discoveries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06988-4

Analysis of data from the Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study comprising mainly of trios and mother–infant pairs reveals novel East Asian-specific genetic associations with maternal bile acid, gestational weight gain and infant cord blood traits.
item.dc:title: The Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study enables generational genetic discoveries

item.title: SHR and SCR coordinate root patterning and growth early in the cell cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06971-z

Quantitative time-resolved microscopy analysis of SHR and SCR dynamics in single cells of living Arabidopsis roots shows that these transcription factors coordinate formative and proliferative cell divisions early in the cell cycle.
item.dc:title: SHR and SCR coordinate root patterning and growth early in the cell cycle
item.dc:creator: Cara M. Winter
Pablo Szekely
Vladimir Popov
Heather Belcher

Matthew Jones

Philip N. Benfey

item.title: Flexible silicon solar cells with high power-to-weight ratios
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06948-y

A study reports a combination of processing, optimization and low-damage deposition methods for the production of silicon heterojunction solar cells exhibiting flexibility and high performance.
item.dc:title: Flexible silicon solar cells with high power-to-weight ratios
item.dc:creator: Yang Li

item.title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol dictates ferroptosis sensitivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06983-9

7-Dehydrocholesterol (7-DHC) is a natural anti-ferroptotic metabolite and pharmacological manipulation of 7-DHC levels shows promise as a therapeutic strategy for cancer and ischaemia–reperfusion injury.
item.dc:title: 7-Dehydrocholesterol dictates ferroptosis sensitivity

item.title: High-quality semiconductor fibres via mechanical design
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06946-0

A mechanical design is developed for the fabrication of ultralong, fracture-free and perturbation-free semiconductor fibres to address the increasing demand for flexible and wearable optoelectronics.
item.dc:title: High-quality semiconductor fibres via mechanical design
item.dc:creator: Zhixun Wang
Zhe Wang
Dong Li
Chunlei Yang
Qichong Zhang
Ming Chen
Huajian Gao
Lei Wei

item.title: Ultracold field-linked tetratomic molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06986-6

Ultracold polyatomic molecules can be created by electroassociation in a degenerate Fermi gas of microwave-dressed polar molecules through a field-linked resonance.
item.dc:title: Ultracold field-linked tetratomic molecules
item.dc:creator: Xing-Yan Chen
Shrestha Biswas
Sebastian Eppelt
Andreas Schindewolf
Fulin Deng
Tao Shi
Su Yi
Timon A. Hilker
Immanuel Bloch
Xin-Yu Luo

item.title: Designing a circular carbon and plastics economy for a sustainable future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06939-z

Four future greenhouse gas emission scenarios for the global plastics system are investigated, with the lead scenario achieving net-zero emissions, and a series of technical, legal and economic interventions recommended.
item.dc:title: Designing a circular carbon and plastics economy for a sustainable future
item.dc:creator: Fernando Vidal
Eva R. van der Marel
Ryan W. F. Kerr
Caitlin McElroy

Cameron Hepburn

Charlotte K. Williams

item.title: Deepfakes, trolls and cybertroopers: how social media could sway elections in 2024
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00274-7

Faced with data restrictions and harassment, researchers are mapping out fresh approaches to studying social media’s political reach.
item.dc:title: Deepfakes, trolls and cybertroopers: how social media could sway elections in 2024
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Mysterious exploding star and more — January’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00253-y

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: Mysterious exploding star and more — January’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: An early look at birth cohort genetics in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00079-8

Genetic sequencing data from more than 4,000 Chinese participants in the Born in Guangzhou Cohort Study provide insights into the population, and a snapshot of what is to come in future phases of the project.
item.dc:title: An early look at birth cohort genetics in China
item.dc:creator: Nicholas John Timpson

item.title: Measles outbreaks cause alarm: what the data say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00265-8

A drastic rise in infections in the United Kingdom and Europe follows a drop in vaccine uptake.
item.dc:title: Measles outbreaks cause alarm: what the data say
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Stone tools in northern Europe made by Homo sapiens 45,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00072-1

DNA analyses of skeletal fragments from a site in Germany provide evidence that humans, rather than Neanderthals, were responsible for a particular stone-tool industry called the Lincombian–Ranisian–Jerzmanowician.
item.dc:title: Stone tools in northern Europe made by Homo sapiens 45,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: William E. Banks

item.title: Unravelling how plant cells divide and differ
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00041-8

In a multicellular organism, normal growth requires control of cell division to generate cells that are similar to or different from their parents. Analysis of this process in plant roots reveals how this mechanism is regulated.
item.dc:title: Unravelling how plant cells divide and differ
item.dc:creator: Ikram Blilou

item.title: Forget lung, breast or prostate cancer: why tumour naming needs to change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00216-3

The conventional way of classifying metastatic cancers according to their organ of origin is denying people access to drugs that could help them.
item.dc:title: Forget lung, breast or prostate cancer: why tumour naming needs to change
item.dc:creator: Fabrice André
Elie Rassy
Aurélien Marabelle
Stefan Michiels
Benjamin Besse

item.title: New genetic variants found in large Chinese mother–baby study
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00270-x

The study is one of the first in Asia to examine links between the genomes of mothers, babies and their health.
item.dc:title: New genetic variants found in large Chinese mother–baby study
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Daily briefing: Why moths are really drawn to light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00294-3

Nocturnal insects’ instinct to keep their back to the light makes them appear attracted to lamps. Plus, the emerging field of cancer neuroscience and the cognitive benefits of playing an instrument.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why moths are really drawn to light
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Missense, nosense and nonsense
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00226-1

A literary mystery.
item.dc:title: Missense, nosense and nonsense
item.dc:creator: David Mathew

item.title: Bendy silicon solar cells pack a powerful punch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04132-w

Crystalline silicon solar cells have been brittle, heavy and fragile until now. Highly flexible versions with high power-to-weight ratios and power conversion efficiencies of 26.06–26.81% were produced by improving manufacturing and design technologies and by using thin wafer substrates.
item.dc:title: Bendy silicon solar cells pack a powerful punch

item.title: Ecosystem effects of sea otters limit coastal erosion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00073-0

Conservation is bringing back certain predators that are high in the food chain, but how this affects an ecosystem overall is debated. Rigorous fieldwork provides strong evidence that sea otters help to mitigate coastal erosion.
item.dc:title: Ecosystem effects of sea otters limit coastal erosion
item.dc:creator: Johan S. Eklöf

item.title: How can scientists make the most of the public’s trust in them?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00238-x

Researchers have a part to play in addressing concerns about government interference in science.
item.dc:title: How can scientists make the most of the public’s trust in them?

item.title: How cancer hijacks the nervous system to grow and spread
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00240-3

A new wave of research is unpicking the relationship between cancer and neurons — and looking for ways to stop the crosstalk.
item.dc:title: How cancer hijacks the nervous system to grow and spread
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: Natural inhibitor found for cell death by ferroptosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00080-1

The discovery that an evolutionarily conserved molecule used to make cholesterol also acts as a defence against a cell-death mechanism called ferroptosis might lead to new ways to treat cancer and other clinical conditions.
item.dc:title: Natural inhibitor found for cell death by ferroptosis
item.dc:creator: Donna D. Zhang

item.title: From a pocketful of rocks to scientific director of palaeontological research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00269-4

PhD candidate Dirley Cortés says that it takes grit and guts to navigate the challenges of being a Latin American woman in palaeontology.
item.dc:title: From a pocketful of rocks to scientific director of palaeontological research
item.dc:creator: Efrain Rincon

item.title: How speech is produced and perceived in the human cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00078-9

A neural probe has been used to capture the activity of large populations of single neurons as people are speaking or listening, providing detailed insights into how the brain encodes specific features of speech.
item.dc:title: How speech is produced and perceived in the human cortex
item.dc:creator: Yves Boubenec

item.title: Flexible fibres take fabrics into the information age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00076-x

A technique for embedding fibres with semiconductor devices produces defect-free strands that are hundreds of metres long. Garments woven with these threads offer a tantalizing glimpse of the wearable electronics of the future.
item.dc:title: Flexible fibres take fabrics into the information age
item.dc:creator: Xiaoting Jia
Alex Parrott

item.title: Brazil’s deforestation ‘police’ on strike — threatening climate goals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00279-2

Environmental workers in the government have stopped field operations, and might halt work altogether.
item.dc:title: Brazil’s deforestation ‘police’ on strike — threatening climate goals
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: Embryo model made using pluripotent stem cells reveals details of early development in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04114-y

Early embryonic development in humans remains poorly understood. A 3D cellular model called bilaminoids, generated using ‘naive’ pluripotent stem cells and derived cell types, successfully recapitulates early development and enables mechanistic studies to examine how various cellular components interact to regulate early embryogenesis.
item.dc:title: Embryo model made using pluripotent stem cells reveals details of early development in humans

item.title: Publisher Correction: The persistence of memory in ionic conduction probed by nonlinear optics

Publisher Correction: The persistence of memory in ionic conduction probed by nonlinear optics
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: The persistence of memory in ionic conduction probed by nonlinear optics

Soil health by 2050: respecting ‘soilscapes’ is the key

What’s needed to rebuild Saudi Arabia’s research reputation
item.dc:title: What’s needed to rebuild Saudi Arabia’s research reputation
item.dc:creator: Theeb Ayedh Alkahtani

item.title: ‘Like a moth to a flame’ — this strange insect behaviour is finally explained
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00261-y

Many explanations have been put forward for insects’ attraction to light, but high tech cameras now suggest a different answer.
item.dc:title: ‘Like a moth to a flame’ — this strange insect behaviour is finally explained
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Reaching carbon neutrality requires energy-efficient training of AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00200-x

Reaching carbon neutrality requires energy-efficient training of AI
item.dc:title: Reaching carbon neutrality requires energy-efficient training of AI
item.dc:creator: Lei Guan

item.title: Brazil must reverse gear on Amazon road development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00199-1

Brazil must reverse gear on Amazon road development
item.dc:title: Brazil must reverse gear on Amazon road development
item.dc:creator: Lucas Ferrante
C. Guilherme Becker

item.title: From the archive: Mendelian inheritance, and an enigmatic echo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00234-1

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: Mendelian inheritance, and an enigmatic echo

item.title: Indian forest act faces challenge in Supreme Court
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00152-2

Ecologists, bureaucrats and conservationists say India’s amended Forest Conservation Act will reduce biodiversity and harm livelihoods.
item.dc:title: Indian forest act faces challenge in Supreme Court
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Machine vision won’t take our jobs yet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00284-5

Automating visual tasks using computer vision probably won’t be worth it for many companies. Plus, two-faced AI can learn to hide deception and butterfly effect found in ChatGPT prompts.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Machine vision won’t take our jobs yet
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Research funders must join the fight for equal access to medicines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00237-y

Pandemic treaty is a rare opportunity to ensure pandemic-related technologies are accessible and affordable to all.
item.dc:title: Research funders must join the fight for equal access to medicines

item.title: The journey to understand previously unknown microbial genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00077-w

The analysis of DNA sequences sheds light on microbial biology, but it is difficult to assess the function of genes that have little or no similarity to characterized genes. Here, scientists discuss this challenge from genomic and microbial perspectives.
item.dc:title: The journey to understand previously unknown microbial genes
item.dc:creator: Jakob Wirbel
Ami S. Bhatt
Alexander J. Probst

item.title: Daily briefing: New evidence supports controversial hypothesis of ‘transmissible’ Alzheimer’s
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00282-7

A small study seems to suggest that proteins related to the neurodegenerative disease can be transferred from person to person through surgical procedures. Plus, Japan’s Moon lander makes a comeback and ‘wildly weird’ scraps of genetic material discovered in gut microbes.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: New evidence supports controversial hypothesis of ‘transmissible’ Alzheimer’s
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How to make academic hiring fair: database lists innovative policies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00273-8

Reformscape is designed to inspire university leaders by collecting examples of responsible career assessment.
item.dc:title: How to make academic hiring fair: database lists innovative policies
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: Academia needs radical change — mothers are ready to pave the way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00239-w

The research system must lose its overly rigid attitude towards career progression — and mothers are uniting to make that happen.
item.dc:title: Academia needs radical change — mothers are ready to pave the way
item.dc:creator: Fernanda Staniscuaski

item.title: Cervical cancer kills 300,000 people a year — here’s how to speed up its elimination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00241-2

Without rapid change, the World Health Organization’s goals for tackling cervical cancer by 2030 will be missed. Four experts share ways to move the needle.
item.dc:title: Cervical cancer kills 300,000 people a year — here’s how to speed up its elimination
item.dc:creator: Lynette Denny
Ishu Kataria
Lisa Huang
Kathleen M. Schmeler

item.title: Bacterial prey turns the tables on predator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00228-z

A rare example of the reversal of a bacterial predator–prey relationship suggests that such species interactions are more complex than was realized.
item.dc:title: Bacterial prey turns the tables on predator
item.dc:creator: Andrew Mitchinson

item.title: Who needs qubits? Physicists make light-based ‘qumodes’ for quantum computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00179-5

Careful retooling of laser beams allows scientists to harness photons for performing quantum calculations.
item.dc:title: Who needs qubits? Physicists make light-based ‘qumodes’ for quantum computing

item.title: Spreading paws-itivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00243-0

Marguerite Nicodeme works with Snoopy the dog to bring moments of cheerful relief to people with cancer.
item.dc:title: Spreading paws-itivity
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett
